name: waves
description: Resource-oriented open source Ruby framework for Web apps.
readme: = Waves An open source framework for building web-applications with Ruby. Waves is ... Full-featured and thread-safe. Compact and extensible. Configuration *and* convention. RESTful but also Magical (very important). Waves is powered by ... Rack and Mongrel (HTTP server), Sequel or Filebase (storage), AutoCode (code reloading), LiveConsole (hot patching). == Links * {Web Site}[http://rubywaves.com/] * {Tutorial}[http://rubywaves.com/tutorial] * {Contributors}[http://rubywaves.com/credits] * {Source}[http://github.com/dyoder/waves] * {Issue tracker}[http://waves.lighthouseapp.com] * {Mailing List}[http://groups.google.com/group/rubywaves/] * {RubyForge}[http://rubyforge.org/projects/waves/] * {RDoc}[http://waves.rubyforge.org/] == Bootstrap! === Get Waves # latest release from Rubyforge gem install waves # relatively recent gem build from master on GitHub gem install dyoder-waves --source=http://gems.github.com # get the framework source git clone git://github.com/dyoder/waves.git cd waves rake setup # install gem dependencies needed to work from source === Generate an application # working from gems waves ~/dev/web/killer_app # working from source ./bin/waves ~/dev/web/killer_app This generates a default application in the target directory. The application module's name is the constant-cased version of the target directory basename, in this case KillerApp. === Configure basic settings Configure your database connection using the +database+ attribute in configurations/development.rb. The default ORM is currently Sequel, but there are other ORM layers in the works. The value of +database+ is used with {Sequel.connect}[http://sequel.rubyforge.org/classes/Sequel.html#M000069]. Sequel's current documentation seems to favor a URL-style argument, but we have been getting along fine with a hash. # With the Sequel sqlite adapter, the :database parameter is read as a path # relative to the application root. database :adapter => 'sqlite', :database => 'killer_app.db' Create the initial db schema. You can create a {Sequel migration}[http://sequel.rubyforge.org/classes/Sequel/Migration.html] with: rake schema:migration name=users vi schema/migrations/001_users.rb And you can run migrations with: rake schema:migrate # or with a version number rake schema:migrate version=1 === Mappings Mappings are the Waves equivalent to routes. An individual mapping consists of a request-matching construct and an arbitrary block. When a request matches a mapping, Waves runs that block. In the simplest case, you do all the response work in the block, a la {Sinatra}[http://sinatrarb.com/Home]. The standard Waves application also offers an MVC infrastructure, with a silent R for Resource. An application's mappings live in configurations/mapping.rb. The generated default mixes in some RESTy mappings as a helpful starter: * Waves::Mapping::PrettyUrls::RestRules * Waves::Mapping::PrettyUrls::GetRules Here's an example of a mapping adapted from GetRules: # define some regexes model_regex = '([\w\-]+)' name_regex = '([\w\-\_\.\+\@]+)'; # display the given resource for the given model path %r{^/#{model_regex}/#{name_regex}/?$}, :method => :get do | model, name | resource( model ) do controller { find( name ) } | view { |data| show( model => data ) } end end For convenience, we defined regexes to match the model and name components of a path. The +path+ method registers a block for use with requests where the path matches the supplied regex and where the HTTP method is GET. The parameters passed to the block are the MatchData captures, i.e. the strings caught by +model_regex+ and +name_regex+. Note that you can supply strings instead of regexes to match exact text. There is also a +url+ method for matching against the entire URL. So a GET to "/user/vyvyan", for example, will pass "user" and "vyvyan" to the block as the model and name parameters, respectively. The +resource+ method uses its argument to determine which controller and view will be instantiated for work done in its block. Thus using the example above, we instantiate KillerApp::Controllers::User when we call +controller+ and KillerApp::Views::User when we call +view+. The "|" character, as seen between the controller and view invocations, is a method that causes the result of the controller block to be passed into the view block. Thus, in the controller block, an instance of Controllers::User calls its +find+ method with "vyvyan" as the argument. The resulting object is passed to an instance of Views::User, which calls show( "user" => ). When undefined methods are called on a View, it attempts to render a template named after the method, with the method argument passed into the renderer as instance variables. In the present example, the view will try to render templates/user/show.mab (or show.erb), providing it with @user = . You can, of course, define methods in the View to override this. You can also register +before+, +after+, +wrap+, and +always+ mappings, with the same flexibility in matching requests. The +handle+ method registers exception handling blocks, matching the exception class as well as the usual request attributes. For more complete documentation, see Waves::Mapping. == Running an application cd killer_app # defaults to running on 127.0.0.1:3000, using the development config, not daemonized. waves-server -h 0.0.0.0 -p 3001 -c production --daemon There are also rake tasks for running a cluster: rake cluster:start mode=production # will read the Production config to determine which ports. You can work in an irb-based console: waves-console # or bin/waves-console == Where the Wavy Things Are A Waves application consists of a Ruby module structured with internal namespaces. Thus: KillerApp::Configurations KillerApp::Controllers KillerApp::Helpers KillerApp::Models KillerApp::Views As you might have guessed, the working classes live in these namespaces. E.g. KillerApp::Models::User. The otherwise harsh birth and life of these working classes is softened by {AutoCode}[http://autocode.rubyforge.org/], a sort of mini-Industrial Revolution for Ruby constants. The Waves framework uses AutoCode to automatically generate controllers, models, views, etc. the first time each constant is needed by the application. Waves looks for a file in a path that corresponds to the namespaced constant name. If such exists, it gets loaded. If not, Waves creates the class or module from sensible defaults. For example, when a Waves application encounters KillerApp::Views::MonkeyShines for the first time, it tries to load it from ./views/monkey_shines.rb. If that file does not exist, the app creates KillerApp::Views::MonkeyShines as a dupe of Waves::Views::Base. The result is that you only need to define models, views, etc. when the default behavior stops meeting your needs. === Directory structure ./ bin/ waves-console waves-server configurations/ # auto_load defined for Mapping; (auto_load || auto_create) anything else controllers/ # (auto_load || auto_create) helpers/ # (auto_load || auto_create) lib/ application.rb # Application requires and includes, plus your configuration needs. tasks/ # .rb and .rake files in here are automatically required by the main Rakefile models/ # (auto_load || auto_create) schema/ migrations/ startup.rb # Framework setup. Don't touch. templates/ # Views expect templates to live here. views/ # (auto_load || auto_create) === Web Server You can run on any {Rack-supported Web server}[], including Thin and Mongrel. Just edit your configuration file, like you did for your database settings(configurations/development.rb) and change the handler parameter. The default is Mongrel. For example, to switch to Thin: handler ::Rack::Handler::Thin, :Host => host, :Port => port In addition, you can also configure your Rack application the same way. Just edit the application parameter: application do use ::Rack::ShowExceptions use Rack::CommonLogger run ::Waves::Dispatchers::Default.new end

Merge commit 'dyoder/master'

* commit 'dyoder/master':
  Need to call #to_app on Rack apps.
  Updated gemspec so as not to include old bin files.
  Really shouldn't ignore command line options.
  use Waves.config instead of Waves::Server.config
  Prefer fully-spelled out names, parameters, etc. for easier ramp up.
  Disabling LC default behavior for now.
  A little fine-tuning of the console, monitoring, and manager.
  Added initial version of monitoring.
  Refactored and organized the caching code. Just add direct to config (no layers required).
  There is now just one true Waves command. And it is called 'waves'.
  Logging (without rotations) and signal handling works. Still no LiveConsole.
  fixes / improvements to manager code
  Refactored method delegation to Rack::Request, adding [] for header access.
  Manager implementation enhancements
  Using server restart to do reloading.
  Rewrote server to support manager process.
  comments to clarify simple auth
updated verification suite

name: b16
readme:
== Welcome to Rails Rails is a web-application framework that includes everything needed to create database-backed web applications according to the Model-View-Control pattern. This pattern splits the view (also called the presentation) into "dumb" templates that are primarily responsible for inserting pre-built data in between HTML tags. The model contains the "smart" domain objects (such as Account, Product, Person, Post) that holds all the business logic and knows how to persist themselves to a database. The controller handles the incoming requests (such as Save New Account, Update Product, Show Post) by manipulating the model and directing data to the view. In Rails, the model is handled by what's called an object-relational mapping layer entitled Active Record. This layer allows you to present the data from database rows as objects and embellish these data objects with business logic methods. You can read more about Active Record in link:files/vendor/rails/activerecord/README.html. The controller and view are handled by the Action Pack, which handles both layers by its two parts: Action View and Action Controller. These two layers are bundled in a single package due to their heavy interdependence. This is unlike the relationship between the Active Record and Action Pack that is much more separate. Each of these packages can be used independently outside of Rails. You can read more about Action Pack in link:files/vendor/rails/actionpack/README.html. == Getting Started 1. At the command prompt, start a new Rails application using the rails command and your application name. Ex: rails myapp 2. Change directory into myapp and start the web server: script/server (run with --help for options) 3. Go to http://localhost:3000/ and get "Welcome aboard: You're riding the Rails!" 4. Follow the guidelines to start developing your application == Web Servers By default, Rails will try to use Mongrel and lighttpd if they are installed, otherwise Rails will use WEBrick, the webserver that ships with Ruby. When you run script/server, Rails will check if Mongrel exists, then lighttpd and finally fall back to WEBrick. This ensures that you can always get up and running quickly. Mongrel is a Ruby-based webserver with a C component (which requires compilation) that is suitable for development and deployment of Rails applications. If you have Ruby Gems installed, getting up and running with mongrel is as easy as: gem install mongrel. More info at: http://mongrel.rubyforge.org If Mongrel is not installed, Rails will look for lighttpd. It's considerably faster than Mongrel and WEBrick and also suited for production use, but requires additional installation and currently only works well on OS X/Unix (Windows users are encouraged to start with Mongrel). We recommend version 1.4.11 and higher. You can download it from http://www.lighttpd.net. And finally, if neither Mongrel or lighttpd are installed, Rails will use the built-in Ruby web server, WEBrick. WEBrick is a small Ruby web server suitable for development, but not for production. But of course its also possible to run Rails on any platform that supports FCGI. Apache, LiteSpeed, IIS are just a few. For more information on FCGI, please visit: http://wiki.rubyonrails.com/rails/pages/FastCGI == Apache .htaccess example # General Apache options AddHandler fastcgi-script .fcgi AddHandler cgi-script .cgi Options +FollowSymLinks +ExecCGI # If you don't want Rails to look in certain directories, # use the following rewrite rules so that Apache won't rewrite certain requests # # Example: # RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} ^/notrails.* # RewriteRule .* - [L] # Redirect all requests not available on the filesystem to Rails # By default the cgi dispatcher is used which is very slow # # For better performance replace the dispatcher with the fastcgi one # # Example: # RewriteRule ^(.*)$ dispatch.fcgi [QSA,L] RewriteEngine On # If your Rails application is accessed via an Alias directive, # then you MUST also set the RewriteBase in this htaccess file. # # Example: # Alias /myrailsapp /path/to/myrailsapp/public # RewriteBase /myrailsapp RewriteRule ^$ index.html [QSA] RewriteRule ^([^.]+)$ $1.html [QSA] RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f RewriteRule ^(.*)$ dispatch.cgi [QSA,L] # In case Rails experiences terminal errors # Instead of displaying this message you can supply a file here which will be rendered instead # # Example: # ErrorDocument 500 /500.html ErrorDocument 500 "

Application error

Rails application failed to start properly" == Debugging Rails Sometimes your application goes wrong. Fortunately there are a lot of tools that will help you debug it and get it back on the rails. First area to check is the application log files. Have "tail -f" commands running on the server.log and development.log. Rails will automatically display debugging and runtime information to these files. Debugging info will also be shown in the browser on requests from 127.0.0.1. You can also log your own messages directly into the log file from your code using the Ruby logger class from inside your controllers. Example: class WeblogController < ActionController::Base def destroy @weblog = Weblog.find(params[:id]) @weblog.destroy logger.info("#{Time.now} Destroyed Weblog ID ##{@weblog.id}!") end end The result will be a message in your log file along the lines of: Mon Oct 08 14:22:29 +1000 2007 Destroyed Weblog ID #1 More information on how to use the logger is at http://www.ruby-doc.org/core/ Also, Ruby documentation can be found at http://www.ruby-lang.org/ including: * The Learning Ruby (Pickaxe) Book: http://www.ruby-doc.org/docs/ProgrammingRuby/ * Learn to Program: http://pine.fm/LearnToProgram/ (a beginners guide) These two online (and free) books will bring you up to speed on the Ruby language and also on programming in general. == Debugger Debugger support is available through the debugger command when you start your Mongrel or Webrick server with --debugger. This means that you can break out of execution at any point in the code, investigate and change the model, AND then resume execution! You need to install ruby-debug to run the server in debugging mode. With gems, use 'gem install ruby-debug' Example: class WeblogController < ActionController::Base def index @posts = Post.find(:all) debugger end end So the controller will accept the action, run the first line, then present you with a IRB prompt in the server window. Here you can do things like: >> @posts.inspect => "[#nil, \"body\"=>nil, \"id\"=>\"1\"}>, #\"Rails you know!\", \"body\"=>\"Only ten..\", \"id\"=>\"2\"}>]" >> @posts.first.title = "hello from a debugger" => "hello from a debugger" ...and even better is that you can examine how your runtime objects actually work: >> f = @posts.first => #nil, "body"=>nil, "id"=>"1"}> >> f. Display all 152 possibilities? (y or n) Finally, when you're ready to resume execution, you enter "cont" == Console You can interact with the domain model by starting the console through script/console. Here you'll have all parts of the application configured, just like it is when the application is running. You can inspect domain models, change values, and save to the database. Starting the script without arguments will launch it in the development environment. Passing an argument will specify a different environment, like script/console production. To reload your controllers and models after launching the console run reload! == dbconsole You can go to the command line of your database directly through script/dbconsole. You would be connected to the database with the credentials defined in database.yml. Starting the script without arguments will connect you to the development database. Passing an argument will connect you to a different database, like script/dbconsole production. Currently works for mysql, postgresql and sqlite. == Description of Contents app Holds all the code that's specific to this particular application. app/controllers Holds controllers that should be named like weblogs_controller.rb for automated URL mapping. All controllers should descend from ApplicationController which itself descends from ActionController::Base. app/models Holds models that should be named like post.rb. Most models will descend from ActiveRecord::Base. app/views Holds the template files for the view that should be named like weblogs/index.html.erb for the WeblogsController#index action. All views use eRuby syntax. app/views/layouts Holds the template files for layouts to be used with views. This models the common header/footer method of wrapping views. In your views, define a layout using the layout :default and create a file named default.html.erb. Inside default.html.erb, call <% yield %> to render the view using this layout. app/helpers Holds view helpers that should be named like weblogs_helper.rb. These are generated for you automatically when using script/generate for controllers. Helpers can be used to wrap functionality for your views into methods. config Configuration files for the Rails environment, the routing map, the database, and other dependencies. db Contains the database schema in schema.rb. db/migrate contains all the sequence of Migrations for your schema. doc This directory is where your application documentation will be stored when generated using rake doc:app lib Application specific libraries. Basically, any kind of custom code that doesn't belong under controllers, models, or helpers. This directory is in the load path. public The directory available for the web server. Contains subdirectories for images, stylesheets, and javascripts. Also contains the dispatchers and the default HTML files. This should be set as the DOCUMENT_ROOT of your web server. script Helper scripts for automation and generation. test Unit and functional tests along with fixtures. When using the script/generate scripts, template test files will be generated for you and placed in this directory. vendor External libraries that the application depends on. Also includes the plugins subdirectory. If the app has frozen rails, those gems also go here, under vendor/rails/. This directory is in the load path.

name: sizzle
description: A sizzlin' hot selector engine.
readme:
# Sizzle

__A pure-JavaScript CSS selector engine designed to be easily dropped in to a host library.__

- [More information](https://sizzlejs.com/)
- [Documentation](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/wiki/)
- [Browser support](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/wiki/#wiki-browsers)

Contribution Guides
---------------------------

In the spirit of open source software development, jQuery always encourages community code contribution. To help you get started and before you jump into writing code, be sure to read these important contribution guidelines thoroughly:

1. [Getting Involved](https://contribute.jquery.org/)
2. [JavaScript Style Guide](https://contribute.jquery.org/style-guide/js/)
3. [Writing Code for jQuery Foundation Projects](https://contribute.jquery.org/code/)

What you need to build Sizzle
---------------------------

In order to build Sizzle, you should have Node.js/npm latest and git 1.7 or later (earlier versions might work OK, but are not tested).

For Windows you have to download and install [git](http://git-scm.com/downloads) and [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/download/).

Mac OS users should install [Homebrew](http://mxcl.github.com/homebrew/). Once Homebrew is installed, run `brew install git` to install git,
and `brew install node` to install Node.js.

Linux/BSD users should use their appropriate package managers to install git and Node.js, or build from source
if you swing that way. Easy-peasy.


How to build Sizzle
----------------------------

Clone a copy of the main Sizzle git repo by running:

```bash
git clone git://github.com/jquery/sizzle.git
```

In the `sizzle/dist` folder you will find build version of sizzle along with the minified copy and associated map file.

Testing
----------------------------

- Run `npm install`, it's also preferable (but not necessarily) to globally install `grunt-cli` package â€“ `npm install -g grunt-cli`
- Open `test/index.html` in the browser. Or run `npm test`/`grunt test` on the command line, if environment variables `BROWSER_STACK_USERNAME` and `BROWSER_STACK_ACCESS_KEY` are set up, it will attempt to use [Browserstack](https://www.browserstack.com/) service (you will need to install java on your machine so browserstack could connect to your local server), otherwise [PhantomJS](http://phantomjs.org/) will be used.
- The actual unit tests are in the `test/unit` directory.

Developing with [grunt](http://gruntjs.com)
----------------------------

- `npm run build` or `grunt` will lint, build, test, and compare the sizes of the built files.
- `npm start` or `grunt start` can be run to re-lint, re-build, and re-test files as you change them.
- `grunt -help` will show other available commands.

Make the native check support Rhino. Close gh-185.

In Rhino, native functions do not display as just [native code],
but often with extra information, for example:

   js> Array.prototype.slice

Make sure we're operating against DOM elements.
Running querySelectorAll on a object element fails, avoid that case.

More try/catch arg renamining.

Default to using contains for determining if an element is contained within another (virtually de facto standard at this point - and IE 9 has issues with compareDocumentPosition - not existing on XML documents).
Gecko doesn't thrown an exception on unknown pseudos, need to handle that explicitly.
Add a branch for handling element-rooted queries in qSA. Thanks to Andrew Dupont for the original technique.
The performance benefits of matchesSelector really only come out when used against a single node. Focus just on Sizzle.matchesSelector.
Remove matchesSelector and merge functionality into matches.
Introduce a new matchesSelector method and use the native matchesSelector if available.
Moved the siblingCheck outside of the sortOrder. Fixes the JSLint issue mentioned in c0d8db6157439d9bc3c9a7624cbd7aae57f335da.
Reworked a bunch of logic in the node sorting. Now works everywhere (including Blackberry 4.6).

Removed the browser-specific sourceIndex and createRange sorting techniques and replace it with a generic sorting routine. Most browsers are either providing querySelectorAll or compareDocumentPosition - it's better to have just one alternative branch to work against.
Blackberry 4.6 is capable of finding elements that are no longer in the DOM via getElementById. It only appears to happen when the node has been inside of a cloned Document Fragment. Fixes #6963.
Make sure that some duplicate nodes are still taken care of, in the case of Blackberry's failure. Follow-up to #6952.
Blackberry 4.6 errors out when doing a createRange() for sort, we have to punt and leave the elements alone. Fixes #6952.
Expose getText, isXML, and contains on the Sizzle object for others to use.
Landing more tweaks the become more inline with JSLint.
Made some additional tweaks to allow Sizzle to run in JSLint (based upon the suggestions from Lorin Larsen).
Move declaration of nodeCheck.

Add a fix to makeArray for the Blackberry. Thanks to Filip Maj for the suggestion and testing.
Make sure a boolean value is returned from contains. Fixes #6042.
Centralize the logic for throwing syntax exceptions.

Make sure that at least one argument is provided to .slice(), in accordance with the spec. Fixes jQuery bug #4942.

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>
Moved to a generic solution for copying methods over for querySelectorAll-using browsers.
No longer use arguments.callee or RegExp (use new RegExp, instead) for ES 3.1 and Caja compatibility. Fixes jQuery bug #4251.
As it turns out, the context was being started at a higher root than needed - fixing this speeds up > selectors.
Removed the need for the results set to have array methods. Resolves jQuery bug #4250.
Simplified the isXML function, no need to use recursion.
Expose the sort/unique code from Sizzle as Sizzle.uniqueSort().
Landed some improvements for improving the performance of ID-rooted queries (e.g. '#foo p'). Fixes jQuery bug #4236.
Tagged the Sizzle 1.0 release.
jQuery.filter no longer has a significant need, jQuery.multiFilter is sufficient in this case.
Updated the README to point to the new documentation.
Bringing some test suite changes back from jQuery.
Switch to using createRange for element comparision instead of Array indexOf checks - thanks for the tip, Ioseb.
Brought back the compareDocumentPosition code. While it is redundant in Firefox it's much faster than using indexOf.
Tweaked some of the selector tests to handle some of the test page changes.
Bringing some test suite changes back from jQuery.
Disabled one of the ordering tests that was taking a while to run.
Added support for class selectors and class attribute selectors on XML documents. Fixes jQuery bug #4167.
Fixed an issue with :nth-child selectors embedded in :not() filters. Fixes jQuery bug #4156.
Changed the jQuery hidden/visible selectors to be a little more precise.

Change the behavior of how :visible and :hidden work. :hidden is when an element is display none, a parent element is display none, or the element has a width of 0. :visible is when the element is not display none and all of its ancesotrs are not display none and its width is larger than 0. Fixes jQuery bugs #1349, #3265, and #3895.
Fixed a bug with certain + selectors failing (Fixes jQuery bug #4023). Also tweaked the + and > functions a little bit.
Fixed the issue where weird characters were being used in ID selectors. Fixes jQuery bug #3913.
Make sure that [name=FOO] searches actually have the specified name (IE includes elements that have the ID, as well).
Updated the local copy of jQuery to be more current.
Added fixes for two different :not() bugs. One with p:not(p.foo) failing and another with a weird combination of multiple selectors and filters. Fixes jQuery bug #4101.
Updated the copy of jQuery and added some more context tests.
Provide a graceful failover for [name=foo] queries that are looking for non-input/iframe/form elements. Fixes jQuery bug #4081.
The compareDocumentPosition check was extraneous - indexOf works in all the other browsers that we need to support.
Added support for sorting in Safari - when querySelectorAll isn't able to be used.
Disabled expando selector tests - they don't work in all browsers.
Oops, the sourceIndex of the documentElement in IE is 1, not 0.
Make sure that elements are returned in document order - and that the results are unique.

New caching system

- Uses two vars per element instead of adding properties every query, reducing memory usage
- slightly faster in Opera
- *HUGE* speed up in Firefox

Re-merging the fix from LosTFx that optimizes dirCheck/dirNodeCheck.

nextSibling selector speed up

removed Sizzle.filter in nextSibling selector, when part is a tag
Speed up [expecially for IE]

Added caching to the first element in dirNodeCheck and dirCheck when searching for the previous sibling. (Patch by LosTFx - had to apply manually, did not apply cleanly.)
Temporarily revert the nodeType check (so some other patches land cleanly).

Removed elem.nodeType test from dirNodeCheck and dirCheck

Big general speed UP

filter.CHILD rewrite

Removed cache for only-child, first-child and last-child, using specific loops to speed up.

Added an extra check in prefilter.CLASS to speed up IE

Bringing some test suite changes back from jQuery.
Reworked the attribute selection code to be able to select false-y values - and added some tests to verify that they work well against expandos.
match[4] is already saved in check - thanks Balazs.
Added a fix for empty attribute selection values. Fixes jQuery bug #3990.
Added logic for not using getElementsByClassName in different failure states. Fixes jQuery bugs #4058 and #4042.
Added some extra tests for IDs with dashes and underscores in them.
Made the getAttribute check more explicit - comment nodes don't have getAttribute in XUL documents. Fixes jQuery bug #3870.
Bumping Sizzle version to 0.9.3.
Tweaked one of the selector tests.
Added some additional checks to make sure that the correct methods are being used in IE on XML documents.
Bumping the version of Sizzle up to 0.9.2.
A follow-up for bug #3945. ID selectors don't work in querySelectorAll on XML documents, so we just fall back to the normal engine.

Make sure that [name=foo] and #id selectors don't use the native methods on XML documents (since id and name attributes may not be defined by a DTD and will return nothing instead. Fixes jQuery bug #3945.

Now handle the case where Safari's querySelectorAll fails on uppercase characters in quirks mode. Added a test to check for it and re-worked some of the existing tests to better handle document order issues. Fixes jQuery bug #3840.

After discussing it with a number of users I've decided to revert the change to [name!=value]. It is now equal to :not([attr!=value]). Attempting to switch it to [attr]:not([attr!=value]) produced some really non-obvious results and confused users. Fixes jQuery bug #3884.
CHILD positions were being cached improperly. Tweaked it and added a test to make sure it doesn't happen again. Fixes jQuery bug #3924.
Fixed a missing semicolon. Fixes jQuery bug #3927.
Added a performance improvement to preFilter.CLASS from LosT on the Sizzle.js mailing list.
Added support for a[name^='foo['] style selectors. Fies jQuery bug #3928.
Made sure that a child element exists before the check is done, fixes jQuery bug #3870.
Bringing some test suite changes back from jQuery.
Re-worked the logic for handling isXML detection.
Bringing some test suite changes back from jQuery.
Fixed the logic for determining if an XML file is being used. Fixes jQuery bug #3896.
Added in a more-recent version of jQuery.
Tweaked a couple tests.
Got selectors like "div > :not(:first)" working again. Closes jQuery bug #3814.
Loosened the logic around the particular filter loop (only != null is needed). Fixes jQuery bug #3816.
Removed escaping logic from attribute names. Fixes jQuery Bug #3729.
Reworked the logic for handling positional selectors. Now works smoothly for multi-layer-deep positionals. Was also able to remove some redundant goodArray logic from filter. Fixed jQuery bug #3873.
Made the check for getElementsByClassName a little more explicit.
The logic for filtering classes was breaking if an early node wasn't matched. Fixes jQuery bug #3848.
Fixed a never-ending loop bug with div filters. Fixes jQuery bug #3837.
Merged selector test suite changes back from jQuery.
Make sure that expandos aren't added to XML nodes.

Make sure that the href attribute in the selector tests points to a
relative URL.
Added a fix for extra spacing around attribute selectors.
Added a fix for handling normalized href attributes.
Added a fix for breaking contextual positional selectors "> :first".
Made a tweak to the CHILD filter caching logic.
PSEUDO selectors were attempting to process POS selectors - which was causing problems with :not(:first).

Spelling of 'gzipped' from 'gipped'

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>
Assigning the copyright to the Dojo Foundation (Sizzle was accepted as a project) - bumping the version to 0.9.1.
Fixed an issue with nodeName comparisons failing on XML documents.
Backslashes weren't being removed from the ID filter.
Needed a positive lookahead for the POS RegExp.
Increases the unicode range of characters matched in selectors, fixes jQuery ticket #3630.
Added some RegExp fixes (they were being too greedy). Thanks to Balazs for the tips.
Added support for [for] attribute selectors - and added some extra tests.
Added the three licenses to the LICENSE file and added a URL to the project page to the source header.
Tri-licensing Sizzle. BSD for possible use by the YUI project, GPL for compliance with jQuery (and thus the Drupal project).
Removed old doCache line.
Removed usage of instanceof Array in favor of the object toString technique.
Forgot to pass along the array of results when qSA is used.
Added a bunch of performance improvements. Don't do unnecessary array conversion, improved CLASS filtering, improved :not filtering.
Oops, order of operations.
.contains() doesn't exist on XML elements in IE, make its use optional.
Forgot to pass along seed and matches when qSA is used.
Forgot to pass along the seed argument to Sizzle.
Switched jQuery's multiFilter to use Sizzle.matches instead (which is much more efficient).
Missed adding in support for :animated in jQuery.
Fixed :not() functionality, made it work with :not(div #a) and with :not(:first).
Fixed an issue with multiple-depth filters failing with an incorrect parser error.
Updated jQuery to jQuery 1.3b2pre and disabled the core tests in the test suite.
Resolved the conflict.
Fixed it so that selectors only match the correct fragments, not portions inside other selectors (e.g. :not(#id) and [name=:some.value]).

Add failing test for attribute selector with a "." (e.g. a[href='http://www.google.com/']).

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Don't consider selector expressions with a comma (",") in them as "simple". This fixes a bug where Sizzle is incorrectly passed a "not()" non-simple selector such as "not:(#mark, code)".

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Run core.js unit tests too, and add a failing test for not('ID, tag selector').

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Fix test broken by addition of form#name-tests in a previous commit.

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Fix selector for grouped name attributes (e.g. "input[name='types[]']") not being recognized as a valid selector expression.

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Add missing semi-colons.

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Call getElementsByName conditionally in NAME selector function so that we don't incorrectly call it on a context that doesn't support the getElementsByName method (at this time, only the DOM Document object supports getElementsByName).

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Allow name selectors with quotes (e.g. "input[name='foo']" vs "input[name=foo]") to use the NAME selector strategy (rather than falling back to the TAG strategy) and add a test suite for name selectors.

Signed-off-by: John Resig <jeresig@gmail.com>

Add a note about how to run tests for jQuery with Sizzle.

Updated the README to have a more-comprehensive feature list.
Removing the caching code for Firefox and Opera - caused a severe negative performance impact for those browsers.
Positional selectors were being placed into the checkSet rather than the normal set - and a filter was also queueing up more results than need be.
Removed the function declaration in favor of assigning to a variable (since it's in an if block). Thanks kangax for the suggestion.
Sizzle was being exposed, accidentally, when qSA was around.

IE8 freaks out when you access out-of-bounds properties on the NodeSet,
provided a workaround.

Removed an unnecessary line which was causing problems with class
filters.
Fixed an issue with how the IE comment handling was working.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:jeresig/sizzle
Added a fix for handling comment nodes from gEBTN("*") in IE.
Merge branch 'master' of git@github.com:jeresig/sizzle
Tweaked the speed test suite to run more times.
Tweaked the selector tests (there was disagreement between browsers as to if :enabled should make [type=hidden] elements, or not - not a huge issue, imo).
Tweaked the copyright header.
Provided a fallback for attributes that aren't immediately available in the DOM.
Changed to using 'root' instead of 'head' (which is a more appropriate name).
Positional selectors weren't handling multi-selectors properly "div:first, div:last".

Completely re-worked how positional selectors are handled (e.g. :first, :last, etc.). They were handled within the context of an individual query before rather than from a top-down manner which users expect.
Modifed the test file to pull in the jQuery/Sizzle hybrid file.
Fixed an issue where makeArray wasn't appending items to an existing array in makeArray - only if a proper array was passed in.
Fixed ~= to work on space-separated values, not just doing a match.
The head element doesn't exist in documents that don't explictly define one in WebKit - use documentElement instead (still works).
Selectors with no context (thus defaulting to a context of document) was causing errors when a .contextDocument was used (which is null on document).
Removed browser-specific checks for handling makeArray and the getElementById(someName) problems.
Minor tweak to the *-child caching code.
Added support for Sizzle("> div", context) (along with + and ~ as well).

Tweaked the getElementsByClassName detection code to look for the method on the documentElement (which makes sure that custom implementations that are slapped on in browsers, like IE, aren't detected).
Tweaked the contains function to have a generic definition.
Fixing a bug where inline filters were stopping filtering too early.
Fixed an issue with ":first-child > *" (documentElement was getting picked up, which doesn't have a parent, causing problems for the CHILD filters).
Fixed a bug with psuedo-selectors sometimes getting munged by position selectors.
Make the qSA detection more generic. Should eventually move to using qSA on any element.
Added support for a new Sizzle.matches method which takes an expression and an array of elements - which are filtered based upon the expression.
Expose the old jQuery API for adding in :foo selectors.
Forgot to restore the selectors object after qSA is introduced.
Forced contextual selectors (Sizzle("div", document.body)) to have the full selector be contained within the context.
Added more features to the jQuery-specific Sizzle code - now serves as a complete drop-in replacement for the existing src/selector.js file in jQuery.
Make sure that the context actually is a DOM element or DOM document.

Moved the library-specific code outside of Sizzle and added an extra build script to add it back
in again.
No longer expose window.Sizzle if a library already exists. Also expose Expr as Sizzle.selectors.
Landing an improvement to .class performance.
Improved the performance of "div > p", "div, p", and "div p" selectors.
Reorganized the directional search code (resulting in less function calls).
Added the MIT license and copyright notice to the sizzle.js file.
Added the MIT license to the code.
Updated the performance testing frameworks.
Updated the readme to be more current.
Tweaked the caching code (saves an array copy, instead of the original).

Sizzle now passes all tests in IE 6, Firefox 3, and Safari 3.1. (One test fails in Firefox 3.1, one test fails in Opera 9.51)

Fixed:
- Fixed more cases of erroneous ID override in IE.
- .substr(-1) doesn't work in IE.

This change makes extending Sizzle with complex pseudo selectors more difficult. While it is still possible to add new "simple" pseudo selectors through the Sizzle.selectors.filters object, it excludes pseudo selectors that require a custom preFilter method. 

For example, in my column selector plugin (http://github.com/bramstein/javascript/blob/master/src/column-selector/jquery.column.js) I use a preFilter method to build a row and column span cache which is then used in the actual filter method. This approach used to work in earlier versions of Sizzle, but breaks with this change. Is there some other approach to construct pseudo selectors with a preFilter method, or is this use-case not supported?

I'm in the process of staging some code for testing that will revert to using sourceIndex for our users.  I attempted to create a test case based on khs4473's suggestion that the original "fix" might be the result of unpredictability due to unattached nodes.  What I discovered is that mixing and matching unattached nodes and using .unique() to sort them, returns unpredictable results regardless of this change in both IE6 and Firefox (with naturally different unpredictability).

I don't know what problem this patch was intended to fix, because John has only vaguely stated problems with sourceIndex in these notes and in #7341 without giving any reproducible steps nor any test cases.  I certainly agree that the sourceIndex code as it existed in 1.4.2 made incorrect assumptions and needed to be fixed, but those problems were addressable.  In IE6, IE7 and IE8, the provided "generic sorting routine" flat out does not meet an acceptable level of performance.  I also realize that "it's better to have just one alternative branch to work against" however jquery's, and specifically sizzle's whole point is to hide browser-feature specific ugliness behind an API.  That implies to me that a certain amount of browser-specific ugliness has to remain a fact of life in sizzle where browser functionality and performance requires it.  To me, this is one of those cases.  Will work on getting all of my tests up to jsfiddle asap.

@cmcnulty did you end up making a fork for this change? we'd like to see the return of SourceIndex because as you said, it "flat out does not meet an acceptable level of performance" - we are spending lots of time/money on supporting the performance problems customer experience in our product using IE, due to this change.

No, I didn't.  I got side-tracked by trying to come up with some sort of test-case by which sourceIndex could cause problems.  In my effort to do that, I created this test: 

http://jsfiddle.net/P8aPL/2/ 

It tests to see what happens when you attempt to do a unique on an jquery set of elements that includes both attached and detached dom nodes. (test 4).  As I'm sitting here on right now, I'm literally seeing a unique sorting order for _all_ of IE8, Opera, Chrome, Safari and FF3.6, with no overlap.  It should be noted however that upon refreshing the test with a browser refresh you're likely to get different results even within the same browser.

My conclusion is that making _any_ attempt to sort an element set that contains both attached and detached elements is folly, not in small part because there is fundamentally no "correct" answer to the question.  All of these leads me back to my original question.  When Mr. Resig states that: "sourceIndex was fraught with problems and caused all sorts of compatibility issues"  I still have no idea what he's talking about.  Obviously the removal of sourceIndex from the sorting mechanism did not bring sanity to ordering of detached/attached mixed elements.  The question remains, what problems and compatibility issues does this patch fix?

I did however run this plugin:

http://codepaste.net/sygep8

through all of the unit tests for both ie6, ie7 and ie8, and also created an updated version of the original jsfiddle to test performance

original:  http://jsfiddle.net/ZNf8b/27/
with plugin: http://jsfiddle.net/ZNf8b/28/

And we see a huge leap in performance (from not working to working) in IE8.  The code looks decent enough, so I'm going to put it through my company's QA ringer and see if we hit any snags, and if not we'll probably release with this plugin.

...but apparently sleeping on it was a good idea. I'll try to submit a pull request later today, but I'm pretty sure we can do the `preFilter`ing with something like:

```
pseudos = ":(" + characterEncoding + "+)(\\((?:(['\"])((?:[^\\\\]|\\\\.)*?)\\3|(.*))\\)|)",
...
rpseudoArgument = new RegExp( "^(?:(?:^|,)" + whitespace + "*" + rgroups.source + ")*?\\)" ),
```

which will find the closing `)` for us.

It should also improve tokenize, because an `rquery` would differ only at the end (`$` instead of `\\)`) and `rcomma` would no longer be necessary at all.

I think we can handle this without introducing the slowdown of another matcher by addressing it in `matcherFromTokens`, specifically by inserting the "*" only when needed in the second argument to `setMatcher`:

``` js
i > 1 && toSelector( tokens.slice( 0, i - 1 ) ).replace( rtrim, "$1" )
```

→

``` js
i > 1 && toSelector( tokens.slice( 0, i - 1 ).concat(
  // If the preceding token was a descendant combinator, insert an implicit any-element `*` 
  { value: tokens[ i - 2 ].type === " " ? "*" : "" }
) ).replace( rtrim, "$1" )
```

Thoughts?

Danger, Will Robinson! This equates `tokens` with part of the incoming `match` array by reference, and then can modify it on [L1939](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/cb6f4d6f61c945a470ee64de93b7aa40df49f2ce#diff-97c8c06db741b10ac298cc03c28714a8R1939).
? `.slice` creates a copy, destroying the reference.
No change here btw.

This is [_awfully_ big](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/0493dd0dc4fb8049696a4a421e75d7ca556fe4cd#commitcomment-5143587). I think we can tackle the jQuery problem in jQuery instead of complicating `select`.
The only complication is allowing direct usage of compiled selector functions, which makes Sizzle.compile more useful. It's not that big comparatively speaking.
There are many factors here and I don't see a smaller way to increase performance. Also, I disagree. Anything having to do with matching selectors should be handled in Sizzle.

> `.slice` creates a copy, destroying the reference.

And then we immediately place that copy into `match[0]`. It's not an issue when we're modifying `selector` and `match` in sync before sending them to `compile`, but it **is** an issue when we're modifying the data of an input matcher function without changing the function.
The only reason to update match is to compile a function. Once the function is compiled, which it already is, it no longer has need of it.

Then you should not even set a `match` property in `compile`, because the ["seed" block](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/cb6f4d6f61c945a470ee64de93b7aa40df49f2ce#diff-97c8c06db741b10ac298cc03c28714a8R1924) in `select` will just chew through `match[0]` on each progressive call until it hits a combinator.

I approve of exposing `compile`; it's the `select` changes that rub me the wrong way because I'd rather have "advanced-use" people call the matcher functions theirselves. I mean, all `select` really does anyway is try to provide those functions with good input, which is completely bypassed in the `seed` case of handler delegation! And I am not convinced that the performance problem is related to tokenization or compilation, or even within Sizzle at all—it's just jQuery calling into Sizzle too often in a tight loop: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/c11becbb692f7707443eb2582543dfe96e8319e6/src/event.js#L421-L426
Yea, I was ignoring progressive calls.

Calling the compiled function manually is dirty. I tried that first and I didn't like the direction it was going. In fact, it was more bytes. `select` is useful for advanced usage of compiled selectors for more than just good input, but I think good input is enough of a reason for exposure even if we don't use that part internally. Consider it the companion method for `compile`. It is a better API.

As for the performance problem, I agree that reducing the number of loops is the real issue in the use case laid out by the perf. SelectorSet's solution is to group all delegated selectors and only drill down into a particular group after a preliminary short match. Implementing that is a lot more bloat. On top of that, it is completely specialized.

The other option presented so far is bringing back quickIs, which I don't like because it duplicates selector code and just says to me that Sizzle could do it better. Skipping selector compilation for event delegation is both logical and a performance improvement (I've seen 20x in some tests). I think it is worth the bytes (which will be fewer now btw).
[-12](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/f83f57d5eaf881015ad9b1a45903f9ed670cd626#diff-3)
Don't we also want `match` on [L1953](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/f83f57d5eaf881015ad9b1a45903f9ed670cd626#diff-97c8c06db741b10ac298cc03c28714a8R1953) for _seeded_ non-pre-compiled calls?
Also, you've just reintroduced tokenization cost to `select`, which is what I thought you were trying to save.

What can `select` do for the precompiled case _other_ than provide good input to the matcher function (which, again, it isn't even doing now)? If you agree with me that the answer is "nothing", then I think what you really want to do is expose better interfaces in a _planned_ fashion, probably by moving blocks of code around (e.g., `xml` and `outermost` determination).

I was trying to save it, but this is simpler.
1. It makes no difference in event delegation performance.
2. It doesn't affect seeded non-pre-compiled calls as `compile` does it later if it's not present.
3. I've only reintroduced it for non-seeded calls. Since non-seeded calls manipulate the tokens, this seems the simplest and smallest option.
You've touched on it. It also provides `xml` and `outermost` determination, but as I said, this discussion is moot. `select` is exposed because it is useful, not because we use it.

You're right, it's an unnecessary retokenization only in the case of invoking a precompiled matcher with no seed, and then with the expectation of providing it a small input collection. That's a fair tradeoff.

That should be jquery/jquery#1874
This is not just about this error; if we didn't wrap we'd pass the event as an argument to `setDocument` which would be wrong.

Sure.
@gibson042 Was there an issue with the broader approach that required narrowing it down?
@jdalton This is the related issue: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1772.
@jdalton These lines are functionally equivalent, so I'm not sure I understand your question. What is the "broader approach" that you're asking about?

The issue @timmywil links to suggests the generic no restriction approach [caused issues](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1772) in Chrome sandboxed packaged apps.

There may be ways to detect that while leaving the generic approach open to most environments. After all `onunload` is a pretty webby thing.

Some ideas could be seeing if Chrome packaged apps have `'onunload' in window` as `true` or if it errors on just assigning the event listener (then you could just wrap it in a try-catch).
We used to do just that, but then jquery/jquery/issues/1772 happened and led us to b49720582b3e39309c4d762bf2aaacdecd66e51e.

@gibson042

> We used to do just that, but

Yap I get that. I think that since a Chrome sandboxed packaged app seems niche compared to IE/Edge support and that since `onunload` is webby compared to something in an application scenario it makes sense to detect Chrome or its lack of support for `onunload` than it does to attempt to restrict to IE (which is causing problems).

Are you able to test out some of the approached [I mentioned earlier](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/28f4c67c508719cc76e2075dce0e4cbe0e325919#commitcomment-11772907)?
Not for at least a week, and even then I'm not sure. I do like the ideas, but I still hate this whole stupid block, especially when everyone has to suffer because of IE (and now Edge).
Yea, I'd prefer to limit this unload handler to as few browsers as possible.
Doesn't adding an unload handler defeat the bfcache on all browsers? If so we should definitely limit the damage to IE/Edge but that is a pretty heavy penalty to bear.

@gibson042 

> Not for at least a week, and even then I'm not sure. I do like the ideas, but I still hate this whole stupid block, especially when everyone has to suffer because of IE (and now Edge).

That's cool. It can wait a week.
FWIW this issue will be tackled on the MS side but currently not planned in the pending MS Edge release.

@timmywil @dmethvin 
_To help frame (no pun intended) this in the appropriate context:_

From what I've seen bfcache support is a mixed bag across browsers in terms of events/features and the scope of the issue is further reduced because it --only applies-- to iframes.

The last time I checked, it was a long while ago, jQuery's iframe support story (scripting from parent to iframe) wasn't 100% baked/worked-through yet. With that in mind I think having this handled with minimal restrictions is appropriate for the iframe scenario.

And remember, before the Chrome sandboxed packaged apps issue the fix in question didn't have a vendor guard and everyone was OK with it having a reduced blast radius (being for iframes only). See https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/pull/231.

> FWIW this issue will be tackled on the MS side but currently not planned in the pending MS Edge release.

No surprise there; it was first [reported](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/802251/script70-permission-denied-error-when-trying-to-access-old-document-from-reloaded-iframe) against the _IE11_ release preview.

> everyone was OK with it having a reduced blast radius (being for iframes only)

"OK" is [a bit strong](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/pull/231/files#diff-88f3c23061b4e51e832a730dc0d97356R478), but point taken. I would not object to once again applying it to all browsers.

@gibson042

> I would not object to once again applying it to all browsers.

Rock! I'd still like to see if the other guards [mentioned earlier](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/commit/28f4c67c508719cc76e2075dce0e4cbe0e325919#commitcomment-11772907) help.
Once you're able to test I'm happy to do the leg work on the PR.

I would _really_ like to figure out a way to prevent this from being applied to all browsers, since it has several negative effects. 

> The last time I checked, it was a long while ago, jQuery's iframe support story (scripting from parent to iframe) wasn't 100% baked/worked-through yet.

Due to the special cases I'm not sure we could ever completely bake or work through them. Cross-frame queries are such a shakey edge case, and I hate them with great passion, but people do them and from a legacy standpoint we've supported it.

To me the ideal resolution here would be for Edge to not throw for this case, or for us to have some way to detect Edge and avoid the cross-iframe access of death. I suppose we could `¯\_(ツ)_/¯` our way out of it and let Edge throw but we have historically tried to avoid those kinds of potholes for devs.

We've tried to avoid try/catch in general because of both the perf concerns (they tend to be excluded from optimization) and the reliability concerns (we sometimes catch errors we don't want to mute).

Well, the `documentMode` check doesn't exist in latest stable versions (2.1.4/1.11.3) and there is still some time before we release the final. I'm not sure how often will Edge receive bug fixes but if often enough it is possible it's fixed before we release 3.0.0 (unless the issue is complicated enough it might take a lot of time for the Edge team).

@jdalton 

> Some ideas could be seeing if Chrome packaged apps have 'onunload' in window as true or if it errors on just assigning the event listener (then you could just wrap it in a try-catch).

The property exists, it just throws on assignment.

We could check if `window.chrome.app` exists but I fear we'll be going further down the rabbit hole, finding more & more environments where sth like that might be a problem and listing them all doesn't seem to be a good solution.

I'm fine with removing the `documentMode` guard then, although we'd be _very thrilled_ if this was fixed before we release jQuery 3.0.0 and we could revert the revert.

To summarize my position: I'm committed to supporting the "select after iframe selection context is replaced" case, which happens to be problematic only in Microsoft browsers from IE9 onwards, and would like to do so without saddling _other_ clients with the fix (the source of my frustration when the bug's persistence into IE11 meant we could no longer cover it with `attachEvent`).

If this doesn't get fixed in Edge, I'm inclined to remove the `documentMode` test and allow an annoying but harmless error to be logged in unusual environments like Chrome Apps. We will _not_ check for them explicitly, though—`documentMode` was a borderline call, and ultimately an ineffective one to boot (which at this point might not even make it into a single jQuery release).
Awesome! I think it'd be good to err on the side of it not getting fixed for Edge because it's easier to change once it's fixed than to fire drill if it's not.
It's `IE <= 8`, only IE9+ has SVG support.

It should say `Edge 12+`, we should always put versions under support comments.

And yeah, that applies to the above comment as well, we just didn't know back then what's the Edge versioning strategy, now we do.

issue.title: Selector: Prevent seeded invocations from cutting off the qSA path
issue.body: Fixes gh-393

issue.title: Misc: Update jQuery Foundation to JS Foundation
issue.body: cc @kborchers

issue.title: Performance impact: sizzle don't use querySelectorAll for specific selector after using $('...').filter('selector')
issue.body:
## Steps to reproduce
1) Use filter, for example `$('any selector').filter('a, div')` (useless but it's just an example).
2) Call `$('a, div')` and sizzle wouldn't use querySelectorAll!

That happends because there compilerCache exists for that selector (it was cached when we called filter).

Example: http://jsbin.com/qidopuhiro/1/edit?js,console,output
1 ms vs 15 ms in my case (desktop).

## Why that happends?
See https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/abde99f6dc2ed3d489a6d7a52f3df9774be16a32/src/sizzle.js#L295

We can just remove this line. Or do something more complex (like marking cache as filter-only).

You can say "hey, that's just a 15 ms!". But that's much slower on mobile (for example 10 ms vs 150 ms) or when there's many selectors or selectors are complex.
Anyway, why not to use querySelectorAll in cases when we can use it.

issue.title: Update sizzle.js
issue.body: use `Sizzle.escape` instead of duplicate-it

issue.title: Core: autoDocument to control setDocument() auto-switch - patching #292
issue.body:
Patching #292 

This change doesn't really solve #292 - but it's a quick-fix that at least give a way to disable setDocument() automatic document switch - when it's not needed or not wanted. One of the cases I was struggling with is that inside iframe - I had interval that was checking sth small from parent window, like $(element).offset() - and then inside interval it continues working with iframe elements. I also had mutation listener that is watching for new elements added to DOM. Sizzle was constantly adding temporary elements. And the performance compared to old jQuery (1.8.3 - that doesn't have setDocument) was devastated. Basically setDocument was happening twice with each setInterval callback. 

Possible usage to disable setDocument auto document switch:

`jQuery.find.autoDocument = false;`

By default it's obviously enabled

Firefox works fine though. Desktop browser seem to handle it fine.

issue.title: Limit all test suite selection operations to #qunit-fixture
issue.body:
Cf. jquery/jquery/issues/2880

This issue should close when one of the following two conditions are satisfied:
- Someone adds a comment certifying that they have examined all unit tests and found no selections scoped so broadly that they could match QUnit output.
- A commit lands on the `master` branch claiming to correct all such selections (e.g., by either scoping more tightly or—for those that are explicitly document-scope—reducing with `jQuery#filter( "#qunit-fixture *" )` before comparing to expected results).

issue.title: Publish a changelog in GitHub
issue.body: The next release will be adding some surface area, and the one after that breaking some little-used interfaces. Such changes need to be captured.

issue.title: Reorganize docs
issue.body:
README.md should focus first (and most strongly) on _using_ Sizzle, since it gets rendered into https://www.npmjs.com/package/sizzle . This includes API documentation currently in the [wiki](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/wiki).

Remaining contents would be better placed in CONTRIBUTING.md and linked to from README.md.

issue.title: Performance of primary Sizzle search
issue.body: In recent profiling, I have seen a lot of time being spent in the primary Sizzle function. Obviously the developer isn't caching their objects themselves, but I think we have room to improve on the sizzle side too. ~~Two items~~ One item stood out to me and likely have some easy wins. ### qSA for the simple cases Edit (aug 2015): removed this one as it was a bad idea. ;) ### fix the try/catch deopt This one's much more solid than the first. :) Because try/catch exists in the body of the function, V8 tosses the entire function into a deoptimized mode, that is orders of magnitude slower. (Thus the warning triangle). It's my understanding Firefox doesn't have this problem, and some next generation work from V8 will also fix this. So it'll disappear in time, but in the meantime it's a _very easy_ fix. Looks something like this: https://gist.github.com/paulirish/cdfce712bba88e264601/revisions

issue.title: pseudo contains uses innerText
issue.body:
Currently, the contains pseudo selector uses the following code:

``` js
return ( elem.textContent || elem.innerText || getText( elem ) ).indexOf( text ) > -1;
```

The [notoriously slow `innerText` function](http://www.kellegous.com/j/2013/02/27/innertext-vs-textcontent/) is not used anywhere else in the code and would only add more delay to processing if `textContent` happened to return an empty string. 

``` js
return ( elem.textContent || getText( elem ) ).indexOf( text ) > -1;
```

There was no significant change in the speed tests after removing the `innerText` function. I think the significance would be obvious with more empty elements targeted by the selector.

issue.title: Syntax error unclear
issue.body:
We ran some front-end tests and saw the error:

```
Syntax error, unrecognized expression: #
```

We dug for a while looking for a stray `#` in our code before searching the internet deep enough to realize this was an invalid jQuery selector.

This error message would be more clear if it mentioned "sizzle", "jQuery", "selector", or another string that would make it clear to the user that this is _not_ a JavaScript syntax error, but a sizzle selector expression syntax error.

issue.title: Automate updating AUTHORS.txt before release
issue.body: Our [AUTHORS.txt](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/master/AUTHORS.txt) file is terribly outdated, even @markelog isn't on the list. We should automate populating it, at least before releases.

issue.title: Remove legacy code and align browser support with jQuery compat
issue.body: Whether or not we have a branch that supports the same browsers as jQuery master is another issue. I think it may be an appropriate time to bring Sizzle master's browser support in line with jQuery compat. This means removing all legacy code that supports old browsers that jQuery compat will no longer support (including IE6/7).

issue.title: Remove POS selectors
issue.body:
Of all of the features in Sizzle, positional selectors (`:first`, `:last`, `:eq`, etc.) are the most cumbersome and problematic. If these were removed from Sizzle, it would greatly simplify the codebase, reduce code size drastically, and set Sizzle on the same track as the Selectors spec. Obviously, this would have a major impact on user code, but we could start with a branch and make it an optional replacement in jQuery. Hopefully, we could see positional selectors phase out of Sizzle completely some time in the distant future.

**Note**: this is a much more significant size decrease than dropping old IE.

issue.title: SetDocument runs every time you switch the document
issue.body:
If sizzle switches between parsing a dom document and an xml document, it calls SetDocument every time it switches.  Do you think it would make sense to cache more than just the current document settings?

I created a quick jsfiddle here http://jsfiddle.net/5j9xxocs/ .  If you run a profile and then click on the "ClickMe" button, you can see that Sizzle's SetDocument is pretty expensive and runs twice for every iteration.  I work on an application that uses Sizzle and switches between parsing XML and DOM frequently.  I made a rudimentary fix on my local version of Sizzle that caches the settings for both document types and was able to pretty massively improve the performance of the app.

Would this be something worth adding to Sizzle?  Or is my use case pretty edge?

issue.title: Test: dynamic HTTP responses for unit tests
issue.body:
cc @markelog 

While running around in circles for #279, I briefly thought the issue was connected to `X-Frame-Options` and had no reliable means of getting it to the client. This abuse of karma resolves that. I'd like to land it for now and open tickets and/or PRs against https://github.com/karma-runner/karma to make it unnecessary, but wanted to open it up for discussion first.

issue.title: Pseudo argument unquoted fallback yields strange behavior
issue.body:
cc @timmywil

Spun off from #261.

Our current pseudo argument parser prefers quotes, but will fall back on greedy consumption up to the last closing parenthesis if they are not found or incorrect. We should decide on explicit behavior.

| Selector | Liberal Fallback (current) |
| --- | --- |
| unclosed: `:contains(...` | _Syntax Error_ |
| no quotes: `:contains(Too Ra Loo Ra Loo Ral)` | `Too Ra Loo Ra Loo Ral` |
| parentheses: `:contains(:-))` | `:-)` |
| properly quoted: `:contains('\'sup?')` | `'sup?` |
| leading quote: `:contains("foo" is bar)` | `"foo" is bar` |
| leading quote: `:contains("unterminated)` | `"unterminated` |
| trailing quote: `:contains(Quoth the raven, 'Nevermore.')` | `Quoth the raven, 'Nevermore.'` |
| trailing quote: `:contains(unopened')` | `unopened'` |
| embedded quote: `:contains(It's a bird, it's a plane)` | `It's a bird, it's a plane` |

Other options to come later; I just wanted to document a wide swath of cases. Note also that our current aggressiveness can cause problems with _subsequent_ selector components (e.g., we accept `:contains("unterminated):not(:contains("Terminator"))` as valid, and matching only elements containing `"unterminated):not(:contains("Terminator")`).

issue.title: Isolate locally-built sizzle files from released code
issue.body: Since `dist/sizzle*` are included in the repo, every `grunt` tends to force the working directory into a dirty state, disrupting size comparison and making pull requests less straightforward. We should update the build, testing, and/or release processes to isolate locally-built output from tagged releases, either through separate "build" and "dist" locations or through special release commits that diverge from the master branch.

issue.title: Implement CSS4 Selectors
issue.body:
This issue is here to track the progress of these selectors so we're prepared to support them when the spec reaches recommendation status. The list below should be updated as the [spec](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/selectors4) changes.
- Subject selector `:has()`
- `:matches()`
- Reference combinators `/attr/`
- `:any-link`
- `:local-link`
- `:blank`
- `:nth[-last]-child(An+B of selector)`
- case-insensitive attribute comparisons `[attr=value i]`
- `:scope`

issue.title: Certain attributes should be treated as case-insensitive when comparing them
issue.body:
Ported from jQuery bug http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/12024

http://jsfiddle.net/timmywil/n8zDu/14/

The inputs in the example all have uppercase values for their attributes while the value in the selector is lowercase. When :not contains a complex selector, querySelectorAll fails and Sizzle handles the attribute comparisons but does not account for these attributes being case-insensitive. We can fix that, but it will probably require a list within Sizzle specifying which attributes are case-insensitive in both HTML and XML.
